title: Qiyana's splash art does not convey 'Empress'
body:
(yes this is my second post about her but I just wanna rant about it)

Her splashart is so confusing. Why is she exploding something in the background? If I didn't see her title, I would not realised she was an Empress/Queen. Why isn't her splash art in her city, or sitting in a throne? Why is she just standing nonchalant? If you look at Tristana's splashart, she has a reaction behind on what she blew up. But why is she like posing like a model for a amazon fashion shoot? I'm so generally lost on what this design is. 

Her theme even conveys Queen of the Jungle, but her splashart literally just throws this away.

replies.body: Don't want to reveal to much yet, since that will all come. But I can explain a little about the title for now, before more lore hits. Her title is one she kind of gave herself, she is not actually the Empress she just believes she deserves to and should be Empress. I have probably already said to much so I'll stop now.

What lore could explain really lame character design? She looks like your every year prom-queen with a big weapon. There are still tons of human and womanly traits, tones and builds that Riot have yet to explore. 

You know what would have looked cool for this "Empress of the hidden jungle nation"? A Grizzled, dark skinned middle aged woman, perhaps with big natural affro or dreads.

Or, if they still wanted to go for a young woman they could still have made her look perhaps south american? MAde her hair look more tribal or maybe even shaved her entire head? 

Riot had every opportunity to make a unique character design and they blew it.

>Or, if they still wanted to go for a young woman they could still have made her look perhaps south american? MAde her hair look more tribal or maybe even shaved her entire head?

I think you watched Black Panther one too many times.
She is a self-titled Empress, as per Reav3's confirmation. And it is proven yet again that you should keep speculation as speculation and wait for more official information and then pass your judgement. What we instead get every time is people treating speculations and first looks as basis for their entire religions on how the current design (with nothing else revealed yet) failed in some way because they didn't hit the right subjective notes in every person's imagination.

Whether you agree on her design or not, is irrelevant.
You're hitting that logical fallacy of judging a book by it's cover. You can't know what the book is even about simply by looking at the color of its cover pages or the title, if it's merely a teaser.

Her design is painfully generic. Even if the "inside of the book" is better than its "cover", that doesn't solve *this* point. In fact, if she has a super-original and totally unexpected back story, that would even make the generic visual design even more painful in contrast.

This has nothing to do with Black Panther. It's about not repeating yourself when you have 140+ champs already.

Even if it's generic, so what?
I like it. There's no rule of thumb that says a character's design has to poke your eyes out on the account of how unique it is, so alien and disjointed from this universe that you literally cannot look away.

Here's the thing:
People reacted as expected when Qiyana was shown some form of dashes, invis or stuns based on her elements. They were not pleased that one more champ gets to join "an overloaded kit" club, especially when she's an AD assassin -  even if the trailer doesn't showcase her actual CDs, resource management, skill floor and ceiling, itemization, a unique mechanic, etc. What i can gather from all of this is that they just want a traditional, no BS champion like Ashe or Garen. Flat and predictable gameplay. They don't want innovation.

The same thing happened with Pyke.
Design was pretty cool and creepy and yet his gameplay was again criticized because Riot dared to make an Assassin support champion so that there's more variety of gameplay when you get Autofilled. Just as much as Kindred was the first jungle Marksmen. 

From a character design standpoint, they want the opposite!
The gameplay can't distinguish itself from the rest of 140+ champions and can't be unique because "muh counterplay" while the character itself can't even be human-like because there's too much of them, we need a floating torso with its limbs flailing around disjointed because "muh uniqueness".

I prefer my female champions good looking to some degree.
They don't have to me swimsuit models. But that kind of attractiveness married with some form of exploration in terms of design (like Zyra, for example), is good. Jinx is also attractive in her own way + her whole attitude on making things explode. 

I like Illao's design as well. She's a favorite champion of mine in terms of gameplay.
I'm not too fond of bodybuilder women physiques but i don't think her gameplay would've been projected very well on a body similar to Syndra's, for example. Oh, and we do have a "sexy" cultist too - LeBlanc.

I'm fine with Riot breaking the mold on occasion.
But i don't want it forcefully broken just for the sake of champion uniqueness diversity.
If it makes sense, go for it. If not, stick to what works.

I mean...it almost fits.

The hairstyle is a blatantly out of place piece...but it's a mockery of the old English white wigs of the nobles (some of which traveled to the newfound Americas to eventually rebel against their own country and start their own) and the rest of her is clearly inspired by such Native American fashions of Mayans or Aztecs. Considering it all, I'll go with Aztecs - the most powerful of them, and the most arrogant by far. Her arrogance is that of an Aztec ruler - she thinks she's all powerful, and deserves more. I'd damn near argue the headwear she has is *meant* to be a mockery. Perhaps it's actually a wig she stole from a pompous nobleman? :P

But in all seriousness...it's pretty obvious to me that this new area's inhabitants are probably almost as full of themselves as the Shurimans of old.
